bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 1, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] inquires about the type of speech he should give at the upcoming Lazear memorial. [Hench] feels that Moran and Kissinger would not resent Cooke's inclusion in the event.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 1, 1940
div1.p:
I have been so busy trying to finish another paper that I haven't had time to
write you as to the final form in which you want my talk. I am perfectly willing to con-
dense it and speak for twenty minutes at the least and thirty minutes at the most. I am
writing Dr. Sawyer, as I am so anxious to find out how much of the general story he is
going to cover. I read between the lines of your letter and strongly suspect what I am
beginning to believe myself, that were I to give a synopsis of the whole story Saturday
night, it might be so repetitious as to be boring. With the story dramatized Friday night
and possibly described by Dr. Sawyer in some detail Saturday morning, a third telling in
the evening might be, as I have said, boring. Therefore, I suspect that you want me to
confine my remarks almost exclusively to Lazear, and probably even to my new discoveries
of Lazear, with that minimum of background which will be necessary. I am so used to talk-
ing with slides and I have such a yen for photographs, that I had originally planned to
give an illustrated talk, showing the photographs of the actual camp, unpublished photo-
graphs of Lazear in Havana, a photograph of the room where he presumably got accidental
yellow fever, also one of the present temporary memorial, etc. However, I gather that you
prefer that the talk not be in the nature of an illustrated lecture, but a rather semi-
formal tribute to Lazear. I can assure you that I will do whatever you wish, and if the
latter is your wish, I will at once start writing out my draft. Please let me know at
your earliest convenience, and don't hesitate to tell me what you want. As you know, I
have entirely too much material for one or several talks. I have become so interested in
it that I plan to write it up, probably in a series of papers, or perhaps even in book
form, some months or years from now. There is still much research to do on the problem.

I think the wording in your tentative certificate of recognition is quite nice,
and I have no notable suggestion to make. I wonder whether there should be a period after
each paragraph. I should think they ought to be omitted.

I doubt that Kissinger and Moran would resent Cooke's presence, or his reception
of a similar certificate. After all, when Cooke volunteered for the infected clothing
experiments, he did not know that he might not get the disease, and therefore, to all
intents and purposes, he was volunteering his life as well as they. If you feel at all
disturbed about this, I should think weyou had better not invite Cooke. I have just had a
letter from Dean Jordan, from the University of Virginia, in which he tells me they are
planning to re-invite Moran and are also inviting Dr. Cooke. I had planned to suggest
this but forgot it, as he lives, as you know, not far from Charlottesville, and so far
as I know, has not received any special recognition. I will write General Kean and ask
his opinion. He know the setup more than anybody else and he know just how small or great
Dr. Cooke's contribution was.

Please write me at once about the type of talk you wish, slides or no slides, and
please also tell me whether I will have to make any other remarks, on any other occasion.
I am beginning to get cold feet!

Has Buddy Groves arrived and do you know his address? Could be join us and get
tight with us Saturday night?
